name: Aurora
story: Aurora, born in a windstorm and with a great power of controlling ice and snow, is the queen of the northernmost land - Northern Vale. Although they are all from this northernmost land, Aurora never had any interest in the conflicts between Franco and Bane. She was born powerful and extraordinary. As one of the four Guardians of the Land of Dawn, she performs all her responsibilities of protecting the world, protecting its border, and ensuring its safety from the spacetime rifts and monsters. During a horrible plain fight, Aurora lost one arm, along with her guardian knight. After this experience, the young queen became solemn and cold, silent and full of sorrow. When she rides on the wind to travel, there's only snow and ice keeping her company.

passive.name: Pride of Ice
passive.tips: Spam frost shock & bitter frost (Be sure to hit minions in order not to waste your skills) until you get the passive skill (The Pink Ice). Once collected, any of your skills can freeze the target. Be sure to hit frozen enemies with your skills to deal extra magic damage. Best skill to be used after collecting the passive skill is the Coldness Destroy. It has wide AOE that can freeze almost 5 of your enemies.

first_skill.name: Frost Shock
first_skill.tips: Best skill to slow down your enemies. It has a long range that you can use to stay defensive. Use this skill to slow down fleeing enemies and assist your team during team fights.

second_skill.name: Bitter Frost
second_skill.tips: This skill has a mini stun due to its 80% slow down effect on movement speed of the target. You can also use this skill after freezing an enemy as finishing move due to its high magic damage. This skill can be used to aid teammates with no stun skills during team fights.

ultimate.name: Cold Destruction
ultimate.tips: When in passive mode, it has wide AOE that can freeze up to 5 enemies. Aim this skill accurately to harass enemies. Use this skill as a finishing move. With its high magic damage you can land a Savage in a single blow.
